docs.snippet: GOLDSTONE--Jonas Melvin, MD, 83, beloved husband of Joan Kaweske Goldstone, father to Amy Trumpeyter Seibert and John Goldstone, brother to Martin Mickey Goldstone and grandfather to Violet Goldstone and Lola and Aaron Seibert, died peacefully at ...
docs.lead_paragraph: GOLDSTONE--Jonas Melvin, MD, 83, beloved husband of Joan Kaweske Goldstone, father to Amy Trumpeyter Seibert and John Goldstone, brother to Martin Mickey Goldstone and grandfather to Violet Goldstone and Lola and Aaron Seibert, died peacefully at his home surrounded by his family on September 7th, 2013 in New York, New York after a battle with leukemia. He was a highly accomplished hematologist and oncologist who practiced in Manhattan. A member of the American Board of Internal Medicine, the American Board of Oncology, the American Board of Hematology, the American Society of Hematology, the American Society for the Study of Blood, and the American Society of Clinical Oncology, Dr. Goldstone was born to Sydonia Weiner and Jack Goldstone. As a young man, his dream was to move to Manhattan. He graduated from P.S. 161 and Boys High School, where he was valedictorian, and then attended Harvard College on scholarship, graduating magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa in 1951. He was subsequently a cum laude graduate of Harvard Medical School in 1955, where he was a member of the Boylston Society. Jonas Goldstone began his medical career as an intern and resident at Boston City Hospital Harvard Medical Service in 1955. He then joined the army in 1957, and served as a Captain USAH, Camp Zama, Japan and M.A.S.H. unit Tong Du Shong, South Korea until 1959. In 1960, he returned to the United States and began his practice of oncology, hematology, and internal medicine. He began in the United States Public Heath Service as a fellow in Hematology at Cleveland Metropolitan General Hospital (Western Reserve University Medical School). In 1961, the pull to return home brought him back to New York where he cared for countless residents of the city. He worked from 1961 to 1963 as an assistant in the out-patient department as a clinical associate in the Hematology Unit at St. Luke's Hospital. From 1961 to 1971, he was an attending Physician at Columbia University Health Service. In 1963, he became an assistant attending Physician at St. Luke's Hospital, and by 1969 he was an Associate Attending Physician there. In 1974, he was appointed an Attending Physician at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. In 1969, he became an Assistant Physician at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, and from 1984 to 2003, he was an Attending Physician at Columbia Presbyterian. Apart from practicing medicine, Dr. Goldstone got great satisfaction from teaching, and he had a way of instructing young physicians that often resonated with his students. He became an instructor of Medicine at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, and by 1968, he was an Associate in Medicine there. Dr. Goldstone was the Director of Acute Leukemia Group B at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital for 18 years, beginning in 1974. He also became the Associate Clinical Director of the Hematology Division at St. Luke's Hospital, and was Chief of Oncology there from 1976 to 1992. He joined the Medical Board at St. Luke's, and from 1982 to 1984 he was its Vice-President. He was then President of the Medical Board from 1985 to 1986. He was a member of its Board of Trustees from 1984 to 1987. In 1985, Dr. Goldstone joined the Courtesy Staff at Lenox Hill Hospital and in 1997, he became an Associate Adjunct-Attending Physician there. Dr. Goldstone served as a Member of the Board of Directors for the New York County Medical Society from 1986 to 1999. He was also the Chairman of the New York County Medical Society on Physician/Hospital Relations from 1986 to 1990. From 1987 to 1993, he was a Delegate to the Medical Society of New York State. From 1989 to 1991, Dr. Goldstone was the Secretary of the Governing Council in the Hospital medical Staff Section to the Medical Society of New York State. He was a Representative for St. Luke's Roosevelt to the Hospital medical Staff Section of the American Medical Association from 1992 to 1996. Dr. Goldstone served on the Executive Committee of the New York State Medical Society for Oncologists and Hematologists, and was the Vice President and Associate Medical Director for the Mid-Manhattan Medical Group. Dr. Goldstone was the Vice Chairman of the Cancer Committee for the Medical Society of New York State, a Member of the Governing Council for the Hospital-Medical Staff Section of the Medical Society of New York State and the Chairman of the Cancer Committee for the Medical Society of New York State. In 1999, Dr. Goldstone became and Adjunct Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Weill Medical College, and in 2000, he became an Attending Physician there. Dr. Goldstone was also a passionate baseball fan and greatly enjoyed his position as an Internist for the New York Yankees. He was an avid sportsman and loved tennis, skiing, and swimming. Throughout his life, loved the city and considered New York his hometown. He could often be spotted bicycling across Manhattan through the park up to St. Luke's, long before it was considered fashionable to do so. Service Monday, September 9, 2013, 11:30am at The Riverside 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory to cancer research would be greatly appreciated

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTONE, JONAS MELVIN

docs.snippet: Chris Tillman took a three-hitter into the eighth inning and the Baltimore Orioles beat the New York Yankees 4-2 on Monday night in a game that featured an on-field confrontation between the teams' managers....
docs.lead_paragraph: Chris Tillman took a three-hitter into the eighth inning and the Baltimore Orioles beat the New York Yankees 4-2 on Monday night in a game that featured an on-field confrontation between the teams' managers.
